values:
Exactly one week ago (almost to the minute) I arrived to the Hebrew University Idelson Dorm Complex, the place that I will call home for the next 6 months.  Luckily, there wasn't anything exciting about the plane ride to report... However things did get a little tricky negotiating three over sized and overweight (as the ohh-so subtle woman at the El Al counter kept reminding me) duffel bags.  Upon learning that I would have to transport my bags to an apartment half a mile and 6 flights of stairs away,I quickly befriended a strong and able-bodied Israeli man.  Luckily, my new Israeli friend, Tomer, was up to the challenge.  
Tomer demonstrated true Israeli hospitality as he "helped" (I watched, and at times cheered) me bring my three bags (I no longer use that term lightly...no pun intended) into the apartment.  As well as helping my roommate, Jen -- a friend of mine from American University -- with her three suitcases.  After suggesting to Tomer he consider pursuing body-building as a field, Jen and I began to cool off from the scorching day and slowly unpack our belongings.  Our roommates who occupy the other two bedrooms slowly trickled in.  In one of the rooms, there is another Jen (a fun southern girl!) and Lilly (who hails from DC).  Both of them are grad students.  In the other bedroom is another graduate student named Amanda (who amazed me by having a huge smile on her face after traveling for over 24 hours) and a girl entering her freshman year of college, Lisa.  Although all of us are from the United States, we are a diverse bunch.  My roommates, Jen, Lisa, and I are the only Jews in the apartment...which adds an exciting new element to experiencing life in Jerusalem.   
The apartment itself is rather bare but definitely live-able.  Aside from the three bedrooms we have two bathrooms, one with a shower.  We have a pretty nice size kitchen/common space which is occupied with a table and 6 little stools.  Off of the kitchen there is a little deck-ish kinda room.  My favorite part of the apartment is the view from the window in my room.  Directly across from the parking area next to my building there is a house that an Arab family (or possibly two, I am still trying to get a final headcount of children/parents) that my dorm complex was literally built around.  Although it looks out of place being a little square cement house in the middle of a modern looking university housing complex, my modest Arab neighbors are merely one example of the contrast that exists in this incredibly unique city.
Our first few days were spent orientating ourselves with our new surroundings.   Although in theory one can live on Falefel (an typical Israeli sandwich of vegetables and chickpea patties that costs about 7 shekel or around a dollar and a half) it can lead down a slippery slope of falefel-ism, one in which I am weary of falling into.  So with my parents on the phone and my roommates eagerly looking on, I attempted to hard boil 6 eggs on our non-electric, scary-1950's looking gas burners.  To date, making hard boiled eggs is the absolute un safest I have felt since my arrival to Israel.
